skill.name: scribe-mcp-usage
skill.description: Operate the local Scribe MCP for any ~/projects/* repo; use when registering the server, setting projects, drafting ARCH/PHASE/CHECKLIST via manage_docs, or logging work with append_entry/get_project safeguards.
skill.summary: Manage project documentation with structured logging and audit trails via Scribe MCP
skill.author: CortaLabs

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill is documentation for the Scribe MCP tool which manages project documentation. Detected patterns are documentation references, markdown formatting, and metadata - not actual security vulnerabilities.

low_findings.title: Documentation-only risk factors
low_findings.description: The skill contains documentation references to file paths, environment variables, and logging patterns. These are legitimate documentation artifacts for a documentation management tool, not security vulnerabilities.

content.value_statement: Project documentation often becomes outdated and hard to track. Scribe MCP provides structured documentation management with audit trails, automatic progress logging, and crosslink validation to keep project docs accurate and accountable.
actual_capabilities: Initialize project documentation with ARCHITECTURE_GUIDE, PHASE_PLAN, and CHECKLIST
Log progress entries with append_entry including metadata, status, and agent tracking
Edit structured documentation using apply_patch, replace_range, and replace_section actions
Validate crosslinks and generate table of contents for documentation consistency
limitations: Requires project registration via set_project before any documentation actions
Only manages documentation within ~/projects/* directory structure
Does not create or modify source code files directly
Semantic search is limited to registered documents only

use_cases.title: New project initialization
use_cases.description: Set up complete documentation structure for new projects including architecture guide, phase plan, and checklist before writing any code.

use_cases.title: Progress tracking and logging
use_cases.description: Log development progress with rich metadata including phase, component, and checklist references for audit-ready documentation.

use_cases.title: Documentation maintenance
use_cases.description: Update and synchronize project documentation as plans evolve, with automatic logging of all changes via manage_docs.

prompt_templates.title: Initialize new project documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the scribe-mcp-usage skill to set up a new project called [Project Name]. Call set_project with the project name, then use manage_docs to draft the ARCHITECTURE_GUIDE, PHASE_PLAN, and CHECKLIST based on our discussion. Log this initialization with append_entry.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new project and need to bootstrap documentation

prompt_templates.title: Log development progress
prompt_templates.prompt: Use append_entry to log that we [completed/found/discovered] [description of work]. Use status=[status] where status is info, success, warn, or bug. Include relevant metadata like phase, component, and any checklist IDs.

prompt_templates.title: Update project documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use manage_docs to update the [doc_name] document. For section updates, use the section anchor. Use apply_patch for structured edits. Log the update with status='update' and include proof links to PROGRESS_LOG.
prompt_templates.description: Use manage_docs to [action] the [doc_name] document. For section updates, provide the section anchor. Use apply_patch for structured edits. Include status updates with proof links to PROGRESS_LOG.
prompt_templates.scenario: Keeping documentation synchronized with project changes

prompt_templates.title: Query progress history
prompt_templates.prompt: Use query_entries to find [number] recent log entries for [project name] with status=[status filter, optional]. Show entries from the last [time period] matching [message pattern, optional].
prompt_templates.scenario: Reviewing project progress and finding specific entries

output: Logged project initialization entry with status='plan'

best_practices: Always call set_project before any other Scribe tool to establish project context
Log progress entries every 2-3 meaningful actions or every 10 minutes during development
Include metadata like phase, component, and checklist_id for queryable audit trails
anti_patterns: Writing documentation directly without using manage_docs (breaks audit trail)
Skipping logging of significant work (violates documentation-first principle)
Modifying PROGRESS_LOG manually instead of using append_entry

faq.question: What is Scribe MCP?
faq.answer: Scribe MCP is a Model Context Protocol server for managing project documentation. It provides tools for initializing project docs, logging progress, and maintaining synchronized documentation with audit trails.

faq.question: Do I need to register a project first?
faq.answer: Yes. All Scribe tools require an active project context. Call set_project(name='Your Project') before using any other Scribe tool. This initializes the documentation registry.

faq.question: What documents are created automatically?
faq.answer: set_project bootstraps four documents: ARCHITECTURE_GUIDE.md, PHASE_PLAN.md, CHECKLIST.md, and PROGRESS_LOG.md. These form the core documentation suite for each project.

faq.question: How do I log progress entries?
faq.answer: Use append_entry with message, status, and optional metadata. Status values are info, success, warn, error, bug, or plan. Include phase, component, and checklist_id in meta for searchable entries.

faq.question: Can I search previous log entries?
faq.answer: Yes. Use query_entries with filters for project, date range, message content, status, or agent. Use read_recent for the latest entries without complex filtering.

faq.question: How do I update documentation safely?
faq.answer: Use manage_docs with apply_patch for structured edits, replace_range for line-based changes, or replace_section for section scaffolding. All changes are logged automatically with doc_updates.
